instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2179: What is A2179? A2179 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2020 with EMC 3302, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01958..
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message: I have a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board that seems like it's bad. Here is a photo of the shorted area. Everything on these lines are shorted...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message:
No need to post any picture, if you write the power rail name.
And nobody else needs to open the boardview and search for that rail.

Also try to make difference between short and (normal) low resistance to ground.
CPU core power rail has very low resistance; <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> in this case.
Post exact reading in ohm scale.

BTW, which voltages do you get on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message: Everything on that line reads 0 resistance to ground. With the board out of the case and not plugged into anything else, the voltage is 20v and it goes from 0.07a then to zero every few seconds. the only two chips that even get warm are the T2 and <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> and they just pulse on and off along with the amps reading.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message:
Compare ohm reading with working board (on CPU coils).
Even less than 1 ohm can be good value.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message: On a known working board I see the none of the same lines appear to be shorted to ground, although they do have a very low resistance to ground. How in the world would I be able to isolate if there is one bad cap on these lines or does it indicate an internal short on the CPU? None of the caps look bad. I've looked at them all many times.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message:
If you get same low value as in working board, there is no short in fact.

The filter caps are more resistant than the CPU itself.
CPU is the most sensitive on that power rail; it will die before a filter cap...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message: So I guess the CPU is dead then? The readings are not the same with a working board. On the working board the same lines all read 1 ohm and in continuity mode they will give a quick beep then stop on the multimeter, but on the broken board they go straight to zero, and a solid beep on the multimeter.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message:
Very low values can be compared in ohm scale only.
If you realy get pure 0 ohm, then dead CPU...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message: For sure it's zeros anywhere on those lines, so I guess the CPU is done. Thanks for the info!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message:
Just to confirm, use voltage injection.
1V should be more than enough; need at least 10A lab PSU.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message: Thanks, I will give that a try. I have the lab PSU. Will any of the caps on that line be fine as the injection point?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message: Use the bigger pad you can get access.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message: After injecting 1v into that pad the PSU goes up to 0.20a. I've have looked carefully under thermal camera on both sides of the board and I don't see anything. Nothing seem even warm.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message:
0.2A into pure short???
1V/0.2A=5 ohm, you've said to have 0 ohm.

Set PSU amp limit to max first; and use powerful cables.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A seems like CPU is bad
threads.message: Oops! Yes, you're correct. Injecting 1v through that pad shows nothing individually getting hot, but the entire area at 10.48a and when touching the power probe it's hot at the tip with a little spark. I guess CPU is done.
